reviewText:
Early Access Review

I will recommend Melody's Escape but it is a lukewarm recommendation. If there was an option between recommend and not recommend, I would pick that.

Melody's Escape is a pretty game, with clean and simple visuals that utilise colour instead of detail to create its aesthetic. The game lets your music be the driving force and doesn't seek to fill the screen with crap and distract you. All of the rhythm games I have played, it is probably the one I like the look of the most. The style of the game, however, comes at a cost, as the visuals are horizontally based meaning that your eyes have to keep track of colours and shapes moving across the screen at often quite high speeds. This movement will cause blur and will quickly tire out your eyes and, if you are like me and are light sensitive or are prone to headaches, the may be game very unpleasant to play for anything but a short amount of time.

The audio detection is hit and miss. Sometimes it works really well and sometimes it completely fails and leaves you trying to keep up with an entirely different beat to the song you are listening too. All rhythm games that utilise the user's music are like this to a certain extent but Melody's Escape seems to keep to these extremes a lot more than other games, meaning it is likely that you will just have to keep a list of what songs you have that work and don't work. This is especially true due to the fact that the game isn't predictable at all: I've had acoustic, vocal-dominated songs work perfectly and electronic dance music with a very clear and repetitive beat fail.

The gameplay is fun and addictive and, providing the game doesn't induce a migraine, can easily be played for long sessions. Best of all, the game has a good variety of difficulty levels allowing for varied gameplay.

Another, albeit small, negative that I should mention is a lack of compatibility with non-Latin script. It recognises Hiragana/Katakana and a certain amount of Chinese characters, usually this is enough for you to be able to find the right song but it is annoying for have half the title or artist's name displayed  in blocks. I haven't got a lot of Korean music but it is possible that it doesn't recognise Korean characters at all, as all my Korean music  is displayed in blocks.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nMelody's Escape is a rhythm game that is designed to work with your own music. Because of this each action you perform is directly synced to the tempo of your chosen song. This game is good at determining how the coloured orbs synch with music with different genres. The background also changes its intensity depending how intense your songs are and speeds up or slows down depending on those factors. At times the orbs felt out of place and not synched up with the song that I was playing making the game feel a little dis-jointed at times. Overall this game is a blast to play and I would recommend it to anyone who loves music or rhythm games.

Awesome game, beautiful visuals and great difficulty settings.  Would love to help improve the game in anyway I can.

Edit:

I just wanted to make a suggestion to the developers as something that should be changed.
The game takes up a bit too much CPU. My game experience is not effected all too much, I have an expensive desktop but maybe others experience problems?
60 fps, position checking every frame and dynamic or flowing animations may be be the cause.

Other than that, pretty damn happy with this game, it is worth the money. What would be nice is a bit of point-candy lol like seeing large rewards pop up on the screen to stroke our egos. That'd be great.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Just a heads-up: I'm writing this review on 15 October 2014. As of today, Melody's Escape is still in Early Access, so this review might not be accurate if the game undergoes more development.

Melody's Escape has heart, and its base concept is so simple that I'm surprised at how challenging it is. The problem is that a good portion of the challenge doesn't come from the gameplay, but from the interface and the bugs.

In full screen mode, the game doesn't register button/key-presses worth a damn, so I played it in windowed mode instead. It works much better in windowed mode, but the timing of key presses still feels somewhat arbitrary. This is most notable in sections that have evenly spaced single notes that, by rights, should have a regular 4/4 beat, but even tapping right along with the song yields a hit only 80% of the time at best. This includes Relaxed mode, where (supposedly) you can LITERALLY just tap one button in time with the song for most of the prompts. I get the distinct impression that this is not because the prompts aren't timed right, but rather, the game still isn't registering all of my key-presses correctly.

In sections that mix button" prompts (orbs) with "direction" prompts (obstacles)
date: the game tends to ignore between 30-50% of all my "direction" presses
recommended: even on difficulty modes where the directions and buttons are interchangeable (The lowest two difficulties). Additionally

voteText: which require you to hold the button

votesTotal: I find that if I press the key a split second early
votesFunny: it tends to register more often
commentsCount: but what is the point of a rhythm game if you have to force yourself to ignore the rhythm in order to play?\n\nOn top of this
column16: the process of respawning after you die is not very forgiving. I find that most of my deaths come in twos
column17: because Melody will fall down

column25: which just requires you to tap away at the same key for most of a song. I don't know if the devs read reviews
column27: or implementing a setting to allow the player to adjust
column28: the speed at which the stage goes by (or the speed at which Melody runs
column29: if you prefer). A follow-on suggestion to that would be two sliding scales of difficulty. The current one changes the fundamental game mechanics so that you either have to use one button at a time
column31: or four buttons AND four directions. I'd like to see a second difficulty setting that simply lets me adjust how frequently the prompts appear. Only having to press the B button doesn't help me if I have to press it 16 times in one syncopated measure.\n\nFinally
column32: and this is NOT a complaint but a suggestion
column33: I would really like to see the "AutoPlay" mode be able to play more than one song consecutively. If you're going to play it up as a visualizer
column34: why not let Melody just run her way through an entire folder?\n\nIf the timing/sync issues could be resolved
column35: and if I could play it fullscreen

column46: one point for the solid concept
column47: and an extra point for the music thing (because I REALLY like games that let me use my music library)
column48: for a wobbly 5/10. I look forward to seeing where this game goes. I do recommend it
column49: but I also recommend not expecting a perfect game. It's still in Early Access and I like it

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This seems to be better as a visualizer than an acutal game in my eyes. Just set it on autoplay, and look at the amazing colors. Plug in a controller too to feel that strangely soothing vibration of it.

For actually playing the game, it is very competant at what it does, though the timing can be strict. That said, failure is okay, as it does not interrupt the song, instead just a quick glance at bleached colors before jumping right back in.

Overall, get this game if only for the unique design of it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I will recommend Melody's Escape but it is a lukewarm recommendation. If there was an option between recommend and not recommend, I would pick that.

Melody's Escape is a pretty game, with clean and simple visuals that utilise colour instead of detail to create its aesthetic. The game lets your music be the driving force and doesn't seek to fill the screen with crap and distract you. All of the rhythm games I have played, it is probably the one I like the look of the most. The style of the game, however, comes at a cost, as the visuals are horizontally based meaning that your eyes have to keep track of colours and shapes moving across the screen at often quite high speeds. This movement will cause blur and will quickly tire out your eyes and, if you are like me and are light sensitive or are prone to headaches, the may be game very unpleasant to play for anything but a short amount of time.

The audio detection is hit and miss. Sometimes it works really well and sometimes it completely fails and leaves you trying to keep up with an entirely different beat to the song you are listening too. All rhythm games that utilise the user's music are like this to a certain extent but Melody's Escape seems to keep to these extremes a lot more than other games, meaning it is likely that you will just have to keep a list of what songs you have that work and don't work. This is especially true due to the fact that the game isn't predictable at all: I've had acoustic, vocal-dominated songs work perfectly and electronic dance music with a very clear and repetitive beat fail.

The gameplay is fun and addictive and, providing the game doesn't induce a migraine, can easily be played for long sessions. Best of all, the game has a good variety of difficulty levels allowing for varied gameplay.

Another, albeit small, negative that I should mention is a lack of compatibility with non-Latin script. It recognises Hiragana/Katakana and a certain amount of Chinese characters, usually this is enough for you to be able to find the right song but it is annoying for have half the title or artist's name displayed  in blocks. I haven't got a lot of Korean music but it is possible that it doesn't recognise Korean characters at all, as all my Korean music  is displayed in blocks.

4 / 5

Love this game

it's so peaceful and pretty dang accurate with the beats~

Plus I can't get over how easy it was to make a custom character.
All I had to do was go to (C:) > Program files (x86) > Steam > Steamapps > common > MelodysEscape > Mods > Sample Skin

You can find my custom character by entering NCS Noche Grim" in the steam workshop search bar.
It just so happens the character I made is the main character in my free webcomic "The Noche Comic Series".

Anyways go ahead and check everything out

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Melody's Escape a rhythm based game that is fun and beautiful.

Pros:

-Beautiful aesthetics
-3 difficulties for beginners, average and professional players
-Simple controls
-Colour coded obstacles to make it easier to detect
-Use your own library of music
-Mod support

The developer is also open to feedback and suggestions on how to improve the game.

Cons:

-Some music may not sync well
-Can cause motion sickness to some players
-Can be an eye strain

Make sure you have a wide variety of music incase some music does sync well.
Also make sure you take breaks inbetween if you're affected by motion sickness or get eye strains.

I highly recommend this game to all people that enjoy rhythm games.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a very creative version of the music runner. The only complaint I have is the graphics actually have a bit of a blur, that you can't adjust and it's infront of Melody. So, unless your eyes are focused on her and you have enough intuition to predict the colors to hit and when to hit them you're going to get dizzy and possibly motion sick. I'm not someone who has a weak stomach nor do I get dizzy on occasion but after 50 minutes of playing this one, my left eye has developed a twitch and I can actually feel the strain in my eyes. Very creative game, but I'm not so sure the blur is nessasary. I'm sure it was out of an attempt to make the game more difficult, but all it did for me in the end is give me a headache. 3 out of 5 stars.

Check out my playthrough at:
http://youtu.be/PxnkNYv_NpA
Be sure to Like, Comment, and Subscribe!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Playing this game for a little bit and this is my first impression review.
Concept: This is a rythm game that takes your music from the library and creates a rythm based game on it. Really nothing new about it but it still works and is still fun. B+
Graphic: So far it looks great. The character animation is smooth and everything just looks very stylized and wonderful. Though a little more variety with the levels artlwork would be welcome. The game is still in its works so it should look even better as things progress. B+
Sound: Takes your music and puts it into the game. If you don't like the music then change your library. A+
Gameplay: Very simple. Just hit the direction buttons when you come across the icons the character will act accordingly. This is where their needs to be improvement as sometimes the action won't register and you will fall. Needs some tweeking and improvment. B-
Overall: A fun and challenging game. Worth the $10 you put into it. B
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Melody's Escape.

Wow. This game's mechanics are impressive to say the least, and the aesthetics are so cleverly done, it's hard to beleive the game is in early release. I can't wait to see what the developer has in store for us in future updates. The game is very user friendly, and the interface is simple and clean. I could get straight into the game with no confusion whatsoever. The particle effects particularly stood out to me as looking really great.

Any criticism i have, is entirely constructive, and does not lean this towards a negative view of the game from my part. This may simply be my screen, but i find that a lot of motion blur occurs, and makes it difficult to see upcoming colour instructions, and it makes the game quite hard on the eyes. I find that trying to press a key to either touch an orb, or to overcome an obstacle is really inconsistent. I don't know whether if this is really my incompetance, but it seems that if you press it directly above the arrows, it fails to work. It seems you need to actually press it before you reach it, and then when you reach the obstacle it will then perform the action. This really confuses me, and i don't know if it's just me being bad at the game, or is a feature. I personally find the intense mode kind of arbitrary, as it simply requires you to press 2 keys at once, rather than one. reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI love rhythm games. This has to be one of my favorite genres next to point and click and strategy comedies. I have played many rhythm games. Audio Surf, Beat Hazard, Symphony, Dance Dance Revolution and now this one. This game is fueled by your music. Not like that add thing that says that as a buying point, like Rush Brothers (which is a good game, but isn't really fueled by music that much). This game is 100% fueled by your music like Audio Surf, Beat Hazard, and Symphony. Even though it is in early access, it looks like it's coming along marvelously. This is a game that operates similar to DDR, but is a little more creative with it, but along with the arrows, in intense mode, you use w, a, s, d to hit the record notes to make a rythm. If you have played Audio Surf on double vision mode, those controls are sort of similar to that. This game can be used with any MP3 in your computer. This game, being in early access, doesn't have music that comes with it, so if you don't have your own music library, then there is no need to purchase this game. It works with all mediums of music. I have played it with movie soundtracks, rock music, dubstep, broadway music, video game music, etc. If it was really easy on audiosurf, though, then you might be pleasently surprised. I have played the soundtrack theme to the film BeetleJuice" on both games and in this one it is fast and lively. I think it depends on the game. I give this game 8.5 out of 10."
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Has Audiosurf gotten old yet? Does your music not feel like it's affecting the game enough with Audiosurf? Well, Melody's Escape is the game for you.

Melody's Escape uses the most accurate audio detection algorithm I've ever seen. Unlike the more popular music detection game Audiosurf, this syncs up the beats with button inputs rather than just placing beats whereever it wants. It also emphasizes held notes and vocals. Everything detection-wise about this game is spot-on.

The gameplay is a blend of Dance Dance Revolution and BIT.TRIP Runner. On easy, you only use one button to do inputs. On medium, you use four buttons for both actions and beats. On intense (my personal favorite), you use four buttons and four directions. I haven't dared go any higher as of this review. It sounds and looks relatively easy, but with the rythym being so precise and having to keep up with the incoming inputs, it all kind of jumbles up in your head sometimes. Melody's Escape is challenging, but gets easier with practice.

TL;DR: This game's audio detection and gameplay are brilliant. Even in Early Access, I highly recommend you buy this. 9/10

PS: It has Steam Workshop for all of you pervs who want to see Melody in a bikini. -_-",January 19

reviewText:
Early Access Review

When they said the difficulty curve was steep I took them for granted. What they mean when they say steep is something akin to climbing mount everest or riding the Kingda Ka. Just about as steep as you can imagine. The gameplay involves alternating buttons on a xbox controller and also using the 4 directional arrows which results in 8 different buttons, four of which have the possibilty of being a long hold.

Now that might not seem so bad but coming at you at anything above 120 beats per minute its downright frustrating, my personal choices of music so far being Trap, Trance, House and future.

I say that to say this, its an amazing game and I never thought I would find myself so challenged by a rythm game. Seriously DDR has got nothing on this. Its also very pleasing to the eyes.

10/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Melody's Escape is a fun and visually pleasing rhythm game that promotes its ability to sync the music from your computer, itunes, amazon music, etc. It is still in the early stages as it is still an early access game. It is like a combination of bit-trip runner and audisurf. With that said, if you have audiosurf, you're probably better off holding off for this game to get some updates before buying another itunes rhythm game unless you really want another. Its a good game, but the only selling point is having nice controller functions for music play.  If you don't have audiosurf and want a rhythm game, I'd probably suggest this one as the gameplay is more akin to DDR matching style, but audiosurf has a much larger variety of game modes and leaderboards.
I hesitantly recommend Melody's Escape. Its only selling point over other rhythm games is the controlls are nice. That aside, it doesn't bring anything new or more to the scene. Pretty visuals to play to your music library.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Had this game since I first saw it released on steam, figured, hey why not? It looks promising, and lets me use my own music to play. Perfect!

Just today decided to play this again for the first time in months, and have to say it still holds true to a perfect way to play/listen to my music.

I'd recommend this to anyone that wants a laidback but still very entertaining way to play and listen to the music they own.

Also the search for your own music is WAY better than other games such as Audiosurf, beat hazard, etc. as it doesn't have to take a long period of time to analyze the track and build to it like audiosurf, or take time to load all possible outcomes like beathazard, it simply looks at the track, makes a pattern, and lets you immediately start playing, which is awesome.

My only downsides to this were when it didnt have the modding for character looks and it just had 3 characters, but since that time, the steam modding community was added to it, as well as more character skins and hair styles, which all still work flawlessly in game. (so far to my knowledge.)

The company that made this game, definately knows what they are doing.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nMelody‚Äôs Escape is not the kind of game I usually play. It‚Äôs much like DDR in that you follow along with music and react based on the tone and lyrics. The game is extremely fun in its simplicity and visually pleasing. The appeal for me is that you can import any song you have and it will use an algorithm to create a new level based off of the song of your choice. While this may work better for some songs then others I have found the overall effect and performance of the system to be quite satisfactory. Since I‚Äôm not very good at these games I have trouble actually enjoying watching the character while trying to concentrate on hitting all the buttons on time. That is when auto play mode comes in. You can select this play mode to have the character automatically play threw the game for you while you sit back and watch. It may sound silly but it is actually a lot of fun. Even though this review is written in early access I feel the game already provides all that it advertises and is well worth the cost. While I‚Äôm really looking forward to further improvements I would not feel cheated at all if the game was made 1.0 right now.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\n(To The Game Creators ONLY...) This game is very fun to enjoy. Not only you can play a pretty good rhythm game, but you can use your own MUSIC!!!   That's Awesome. as much fun as that is, I found some things I am not found of. The first is that you need to press your controls at the exact time as the object shows onscreen, if you don't you will miss it. When I had started, I realized that I actually hit every other note. For people who just bought this game, they would be really REALLY frusturated on this part. My suggestion is to either make the range of the area to hit the note bigger, so when you are pressing the key down and letting it go, it gives a better cance of hitting the note. Or have a calibrator. Different poeple have different accuracy. by having a calibrator, it can give the player a bigger chance of actually hitting the note on there accurate timing. I had read somewhere that you have played Guitar hero or rock band, think of there calibrator, that's what I meant. Another thing is that playing your song over and over is fun, but after awhile, it dies out. The reason it dies out is because there isn't any goal to play towards. Maybe by having you unlock 10 free song of your choice (or randomly), and each time you play a song, you unlock points. Each time you get enough points, you can unlock another song. By doing something like this, it can give the player something to accomplish. By doing so, the game can last longer. Overall, I still enjoy this game and can't wait till it comes out!!!!, I am recommending this game to my buddies!!! Keep it UP!!!!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I really like this game and enjoy the playstyle and atmosphere but there are a few things to be aware of.
I would give 7/10 because:

Pro:
+very fun to play because of easy controls (8 buttons on intense difficulty)
++I play on keyboard with left hand colors a,w,s,d and right hand directions left,up,down,right
+some songs are amazingly fun to play
+rythm and inputs go well together so you feel the music
+concept is well done
+more music = more levels (i got plenty)
+price is absolutely acceptable

Cons:
-!!! if your pc is lacking in performance you will feel it !!!
-- I suffered from dropping framerates and lag to occasional leaps in the song
-coordinating your hands with needed input is hard to learn because it defys common logic
(i didn't use the configuration menue! so i might take the blame myself)
-- e.g.: character jumps down -> hold up, character flies upwards -> hold back
-- on parts with faster pace the color inputs look like directional arrows so i press them the other ways around
-some songs are absolutely no fun to play because input scheme is ridiculous
-after jumping down a cliff you mostly have to gues what comes next because you can hardly react
--this is my first rythm game played as a side-scroller and i don't think it works as well as games like
guitar/dj hero which are on a similar difficulty level but enable you to see incoming inputs more clearly
-some of the inputs hardly ever occur e.g.: hold down color button

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'll preface this by saying I play a ton of rhythm games across a ton of different platforms. I like them.

Melody's Escape is something I've been looking for for a while - a game that gives you a great way to play through your own music collection. I've not had a single song generate a level that was simply unplayable and this is the first program to be able to map for songs with energy peaks, bpm changes etc. I listen to electronic and rock music and haven't had a problem. While I'd like to see a bit more variety in the animations for melody, the mods for characters and button mapping keeps things fresh. And yes, there are several themes to match Playstation colors in the Steam Workshop.
Can't wait to see how this develops further.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This being my first ever rhythm game, I wasn't sure what I was getting into.  But it was shortly after owning it, that this game deeply impressed me! Here's a few reasons why

- It gives listening to music a whole new definition

- The song created tracks are extraordinary

- Sliding and grinding over obstacles by holding notes down caused by held vocals or notes.

- Slow-mo jumping off a cliff when the song dramatically changes its rhythm

- It gives me a beautiful neon colored visualization of my music (other then those wacky Media Player ones)

- No failure state

This game almost reminds me of my days when I played Guitar Hero. I personally must recommend this game. I've had zero issues with it at all and it runs perfectly. I could compare this to Besiege by how well optimized and good quality this early access build is. It's worth the 10$s or your regional equivalent for sure! Keep up the good work Icetesy!

P.S. Some of the mods are really worth looking into for this game. I currently have my Melody as Red from Transistor.

So far I've noticed two three things about this game:
1: It looks and feels fantastic. The visuals are very polished and make for a fun experience in a musical game.

2: As a game; it's just as fun as Audiosurf, but with a different style to it. It doesn't feel at all like a cash-in or knock off of Audiosurf either.

3: THIS GAME IS HARD AS BALLS. the detection is Razor-edge precise, so if you screw up it's usually because you messed up the timing, couple that with multi-handed directional Button-mashing" and it can be hard at first.

All I have to say is this is a good game
recommended: but still ok. It definately needs some tinkering in the Control aspect though

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As a person who loves rhythm games I generally go into them with a very skeptical mind. Of course when I first started the game I found it very difficult and seemed to find myself getting frustrated quickly. Of course that quicky fades as it's a game that you can pick up on very quickly, but is still challenging enough to keep things interesting.

Even in this early stage this game is fun as all hell and enjoyable to anyone who loves a good rhythm game that isn't going to make you smash your monitor but is going to keep challenging you. Plus, on another good note, you can instantly play your favorite songs and the notes actually make sense. It's always fun to watch her pick up speed and have notes come flying at you, and the vivid visuals and Melody herself are fun to watch. Also due to the simple visual style it's not hard to see the notes which is another big plus for me.

As far as I'm concerned this is one of the best rhythm games out there. Anyone who loves these types of games will love this game. Also with it still being an early title you're likely to see even more added on. It pleasing to the eyes as well as the ears, definitely not a rhythm game that should be passed up.

This is my Chilax game. Normally i dont like rhythm games becaues i suck at them. but for some reason i love this one.

Pros: varying difficulties where the easiest is really good if your new to rhythm games, and the hardest will make a Rockban veteran cry. also has a custom difficulty where you can fine tune the diffrent things to make it as hard or as easy as you want. does not come with any music but instead uses the song (any sond file really even podcast or sound effects) you have on you PC. comes with a Mod making program so you can reskin Melody to anything you want, and has workshop support. controller support.

With the fans sounding like it was about to takeoff. this game really should not be pushing it that hard. GTA5 dosent even come close.

overall this game is fantastic 8/10. recommended for you if your new to the rhythm gams or are Phille Collins himself.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As someone who is used to playing really difficult music games (Konami's Bemani Brand of games), I usually don't find myself having trouble playing and starting off on mid to higher levels in most new music games I come across. This one is actually challenging on medium and am practicing more on that level before I try to move upwards. However the game is still extremly fun on relaxing mode, and will help you get used to the controls.

The only issues I have with this game is that the timing can be extremly unforgiving if you're late at all, and not so much compaired to if you're a little early when it is a tad bit more forgiving, sometimes the spacing of notes and what button they suggest you press (there is two for each note a directional and an actual button) you'll want to go for the other button instead and that can throw more visual people off, and after you miss a note, your character stops and seemingly gets hurt" and it skips to a couple of notes ahead to where the song went up to while you recover. Sometimes there will be a note right when you recover making it really difficult to hit and resulting in another miss animation like that.

A thing I would like to see is maybe song recongistion by title

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you have scrolled down this far, you probably already know that Melody's Escape is a casual rhythm game that uses your own music.

I just wanted to say that while it does only one thing, it does it well. It has only one game mode, it doesn't have multiplayer or online leaderboards, but it does the casual single player game thing almost flawlessly.

The generated track matches the music very well, the art style is practical and convenient, loading times are really short. There are multiple difficulty levels, and if you don't like them, you can create your own difficulty level. A failure doesn't interrupt the flow of the game, music keeps playing and you're back on track where you are expected to be within a second. Both keyboard and controller work fine, I prefer the controller, but it doesn't make much difference.

All you need is a collection of music on your disk. Music videos are fine too.

The only minor annoyance is that the game doesn't render all characters in Asian or Central European languages correctly, so if you have a collection of K-pop labelled in Korean, you're gonna have a bad time. But apart from that, everything works fine.

A simple, well-done game. If all you want is a simple rhythm game and increasing your scores for your own satisfaction, this is it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a neat game where you can choose your favorite music then as the character Melody run a obstacle course that is effected by the rythmn of your song of choice, and press buttons when prompted to, and depending on your success rate will effect your overall course. Of course on the basic level that defines this as a rythmn game, (if not aware, or certain of what that is, think Guitar Hero, or Rock Band if you are familiar with those), of course using music from your library makes this a rather unique game of this type, where the possiblities are limited, by your music, the difficulty you have selected, and your skill.

Another rather neat extra is that Melody's appearance can be customized thanks to the Steam Workshop, which possesses a good variety of clothes, and hairs for her, the game's color scheme can also be changed thanks to this.

Obviously I would recommned this game, of course weather you like it, or not depends on your music library, and if you are willing to test you fingers's reflects to the point of wearing them out, or of course you enjoy rythmn games over all.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I am writing this largely in the hopes that it would be able to reach the developers sometime in the future. However, this will also serve as an all inclusive review as well. For those TLDR lazy people, skip to the last few sentences of this review.

As an indie game, aesthetically, this game receives perfect scores. The graphics are simple yet sleek and still manages to have a fantasy/digital vibe to it. As a result of the simplicity behind these graphics, this indie game is able to support up to 4k resolution.

Concept wise, this is as avant garde as it gets ladies and gentlemen. Its a customizable visualizer that allows you to either play your favourite song and lose yourself in the flurry of beats or sit back and watch Melody's elegance animations flow with rhythm. The fact that you can play ANY music with this game a never ending journey that can stand against the testament of time.

Unfortunately, this is where the praise ends: It's greatest strength is also the chink in its armor.

The notes players must hit during the game are not optimally lined up with the rhythm of the songs, especially on higher difficulty levels and faster songs. I am not a developer myself and hardly know any coding, but I can still tell that the program is a little too simple in certain parts. Additionally, I realize that this game does not pick up vocals as parts of the bpm, I used the infamous Disappearance of Hatsune Miku" (If you don't know this
date: just youtube it and you'll understand) to test and discover this problem. This ties directly to my next criticism.\n\nWhile I loved the way melody would speed up or even set flight depending on the bpm of the song
hoursPlayed: at higher bpms
voteText: it became a strain to even see the notes clearly and follow through with inputs consistently over even more than 1 minute. This is because the notes move with the screen and only melody is in the same idle position. This is also why some people recommend staring at melody when your eyes get tired.\n\nWhile I don't know if this would definitively solve the problem
helpfulPercent: I urge the developers to toy around a bit more with the movement of the notes as well as the screen. Could the notes briefly accelerate to Melody's speed as they gradually reach her? Enough to lessen the blur but not enough to decrease the reaction speeds by too much. And frankly
votesHelpful: I think the screen could move slightly slower on the faster bpms (When Melody is flying) and achieve the same accelerating effects (perhaps this would also call for speed tweaks for medium/sprinting screen scrolling speed)?\n\nFinally
votesTotal: the last and I think easiest to implement change is that I would like there to be the option to set the amount of beats while maintaining say
votesFunny: medium difficulty instead of insane. This is a concept that was long introduced in such music rhythm games such as Step Mania and DJ Max. Basically
commentsCount: the complexity of the song (or number of obstacles) should be adjustable SEPARATELY from the amount of keys one would be required to utilize for different inputs. For example I would like the game to display all the beats and therefore much more obstacles (so far the closest I would get would be the highest difficulty) and yet still only use 4 keys (the medium difficulty). This would increase the game's immersion as the notes needed to be hit coincide with the beats of the song and yet the controls are easy enough for people to slowly adjust to harder difficulties
column16: and essentially making it a more intuitive game at the same time.\n\nNow
column17: this review seems TLDR tagged and full of criticism right? But in the end
column18: I DO recommend this game. I just love the concept way too much and I believe that there is still room for this game to improve upon what I have mentioned.\n\nI would say that right now this game
column19: in its current state
column20: is more of a interactive visualizer than a hardcore music rhythm game with diversified difficulties such as Step Mania

Cons:
Looks blurry as you're playing (Setting my zoom as far out as the game would let me helped a bit but the motion just blurs things as you move)
Sometimes the game just doesn't match the pace of a song.

The pacing can be great or kind of lame depending on the song, some songs the music will change to be super energetic but melody will simply keep her jogging pace, other times nothing will change but she'll start flying. Also there are times it seems like the slow-mo would've been awesome but it rarely activates in most songs I use. Still can be really addictive especially when you first get it and want to play through a decent sized song library.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A fun rythm game. Once you choose a song to play, the game lets you know how good of a job it's done in converting the song into a stage. If a song scores a 70% or above, it will be really fun to play and you'll totally get the sense of rhythm that the game is going for. At 40-50%, it'll still be fun to play. But if a song receives a score of 30% or below, then it will feel chaotic and messy to play.

At its best, Melody's Escape feels a lot more rhythmic than Audiosurf does. But it does have some drawbacks. The visual cues are confusing at first because they're based on the Xbox controller's button layout (a yellow symbol means press your up" button
recommended: while a green symbol means press "down")

I really enjoy these kind of games. Melody's Escape is no exception.

I found myself enjoying the system far more than either Audiosurf, or similar titles, within the first 10minutes. There are a few quirks with timing but nothing that won't / shouldn't be an easily polished in the near future. All-in-all a very decent game for the price. Will (and have) recommened this title.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Melody's Escape is a fun and visually pleasing rhythm game that promotes its ability to sync the music from your computer, itunes, amazon music, etc. It is still in the early stages as it is still an early access game. It is like a combination of bit-trip runner and audisurf. With that said, if you have audiosurf, you're probably better off holding off for this game to get some updates before buying another itunes rhythm game unless you really want another. Its a good game, but the only selling point is having nice controller functions for music play.  If you don't have audiosurf and want a rhythm game, I'd probably suggest this one as the gameplay is more akin to DDR matching style, but audiosurf has a much larger variety of game modes and leaderboards.
I hesitantly recommend Melody's Escape. Its only selling point over other rhythm games is the controlls are nice. That aside, it doesn't bring anything new or more to the scene. Pretty visuals to play to your music library.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

While this is a lot of fun, playing to my own music (I've tried all different genres and it is incredible)

The difficulty level between Relaxing and medium is... for lack of a better word, testy.

In relaxing mode, you have two notes that do not mix, i.e. pressing one button for a short time, than another.

In medium mode, you are thrust into all four buttons without preparation.

I hope the developers can span out the difficultly like choosing to have three notes with directions, or just direction keys, because this truly is a lot of fun and it's really good for reflexes.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'll preface this by saying I play a ton of rhythm games across a ton of different platforms. I like them.

Melody's Escape is something I've been looking for for a while - a game that gives you a great way to play through your own music collection. I've not had a single song generate a level that was simply unplayable and this is the first program to be able to map for songs with energy peaks, bpm changes etc. I listen to electronic and rock music and haven't had a problem. While I'd like to see a bit more variety in the animations for melody, the mods for characters and button mapping keeps things fresh. And yes, there are several themes to match Playstation colors in the Steam Workshop.
Can't wait to see how this develops further.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Had this game since I first saw it released on steam, figured, hey why not? It looks promising, and lets me use my own music to play. Perfect!

Just today decided to play this again for the first time in months, and have to say it still holds true to a perfect way to play/listen to my music.

I'd recommend this to anyone that wants a laidback but still very entertaining way to play and listen to the music they own.

Also the search for your own music is WAY better than other games such as Audiosurf, beat hazard, etc. as it doesn't have to take a long period of time to analyze the track and build to it like audiosurf, or take time to load all possible outcomes like beathazard, it simply looks at the track, makes a pattern, and lets you immediately start playing, which is awesome.

My only downsides to this were when it didnt have the modding for character looks and it just had 3 characters, but since that time, the steam modding community was added to it, as well as more character skins and hair styles, which all still work flawlessly in game. (so far to my knowledge.)

The company that made this game, definately knows what they are doing.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\n(To The Game Creators ONLY...) This game is very fun to enjoy. Not only you can play a pretty good rhythm game, but you can use your own MUSIC!!!   That's Awesome. as much fun as that is, I found some things I am not found of. The first is that you need to press your controls at the exact time as the object shows onscreen, if you don't you will miss it. When I had started, I realized that I actually hit every other note. For people who just bought this game, they would be really REALLY frusturated on this part. My suggestion is to either make the range of the area to hit the note bigger, so when you are pressing the key down and letting it go, it gives a better cance of hitting the note. Or have a calibrator. Different poeple have different accuracy. by having a calibrator, it can give the player a bigger chance of actually hitting the note on there accurate timing. I had read somewhere that you have played Guitar hero or rock band, think of there calibrator, that's what I meant. Another thing is that playing your song over and over is fun, but after awhile, it dies out. The reason it dies out is because there isn't any goal to play towards. Maybe by having you unlock 10 free song of your choice (or randomly), and each time you play a song, you unlock points. Each time you get enough points, you can unlock another song. By doing something like this, it can give the player something to accomplish. By doing so, the game can last longer. Overall, I still enjoy this game and can't wait till it comes out!!!!, I am recommending this game to my buddies!!! Keep it UP!!!!

It's also interesting that, when you're playing, it seems that the girl is listening to the same song as you and enjoying a wild ride across it. I can also say that's lovely the way her hair changes color when you hit the comands.

One of the cons (for me) is that you may feel a little sick by riding too many songs, or trying one that's way too fast (I wouldn't recommed playing Stand Proud to ANYONE. It feels like you're Dio getting hit by thousands of ORAORAORA. Don't do it.)
The other one is frame dropping during some more fast paced parts of some songs. I was running smoothly on 60 FPS when suddenly the game would drop to 25 while the music is still going on, and making it way too dificult to put the right comands in the right time.
At least, i think this is just a minor issue that will be corrected when the game is 100%.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

On the face of it, Melody's Escape looks pretty basic and bland. A music/rhythm game where you get your own music and play? Why would I buy this when I could just buy Geometry Dash for cheaper? Well my fine fellow! Melody's Escape is a beautifully wonderful game where taking your own music and playing it is taken to a whole new level.


The Positives! I hate to repeat myself, but I feel like I have to repeat to get the point across; Melody's Escape is wonderfully beautiful. Taking music and using it in levels is not a new concept, but ME (Melody's Escape) makes it FEEL like it is! The variety that you have at your fingertips is astounding! Not only do you have the ability to take your music and play unique levels with it, but you can customize your character and even make your own levels! You can even take other's workshop submissions and use it in game. The gameplay is pretty solid with a nice blend of easy controls. Not much more to say

The Negatives... For all the good things Melody's Escape does, there is always the other side of the coin; the bad. One of my main problems with ME is the difficulty. You have 4 levels of difficulty: Relaxing, Medium, Intense, and Overlord. You'll easily be inclined to choose Relaxing or Medium. And it's pretty simple. Those 2 difficulties are as easy as they get, without anything too hard. But once you have the balls to choose one of the other 2 difficulties, you quickly wish you hadn't bothered. You start the hard difficulties and suddenly it seems like someone turned it into a ROM hack level. And I don't know how much I can emphasize how hard the last two difficulties are! It's painful! Anyway moving on.

I also wished there were more achievements and songs already implamented into the game, instead of forcing you to just get songs. But that's just a minor problem.

Final Verdict Yeah, it's a good game and worth the buy. But if you don't have a reliable way to get music via mp3, you'll just wind up spending a good amount of cash. But if you do and enjoy rhythm games, you'll most likely enjoy Melody's Escape!

The visual effects in the game are quit nice and because a the workshop you have some variety for the effects and character moduls. It is also easy for your self to work with the workshop and edit the character files.

Overall it is a really nice game that I like to enjoy, specials because there are so les rythm games for PC.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Melody's Escape a rhythm based game that is fun and beautiful.

Pros:

-Beautiful aesthetics
-3 difficulties for beginners, average and professional players
-Simple controls
-Colour coded obstacles to make it easier to detect
-Use your own library of music
-Mod support

The developer is also open to feedback and suggestions on how to improve the game.

Cons:

-Some music may not sync well
-Can cause motion sickness to some players
-Can be an eye strain

Make sure you have a wide variety of music incase some music does sync well.
Also make sure you take breaks inbetween if you're affected by motion sickness or get eye strains.

I highly recommend this game to all people that enjoy rhythm games.
